ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Field trip to gas station didn't seem very necessary. Same experience could have been gained by an in class case study with pictures on 5 slides in 15 minutes.Asking students to take an 11 hour field trip to MA during reading week showed little respect for the time that is supposed to be allotted for students to write papers, finish projects, prepare for finals, and attend final exam review's hosted by other professors. I find myself irresponsibly skipping group work, finals prep, and a review session to attend this "mandatory" field trip. Show some respect for this one week where students need independent time to prepare and move the field trip to a weekend.

The field trips were very conducive to learning the material and applying the information taught in the classroom. However, the full day field trip during reading week was somewhat unfair to students who needed that time to study for finals. Having the trip on a Saturday would have been better.

Field trips were definitely interesting but I am unsure how much I learned from them and the final was surprisingly heavy on questions about them. The last field trip especially was perhaps too much driving to be worth the content?
Shimi is an incredible professor. I would recommend this course to EVERYONE, especially to people with interests in land and water.

This was of the two best courses I've taken at F&ES, hands down. I was one of two auditors, which gives me little incentive to inflate my opinion of either the instructor or the way the material was presented. Dr. Anisfeld presented complex material in a clear, incredibly interested way -- and constantly sought opportunities to improve students' understanding through the use of field trips, out of class sessions, and guest lectures.
Shimi is an amazing instructor...always available to help.

Shimi--he is a treasure among FES faculty. Although he is demanding and expects a lot from his students, he is also very open and willing to explain complex concepts as many times as is needed for students to understand them. He is also very even-handed in his presentation of material, and will give both the "environmentalist" side and the "industry" side of the story when there is disagreement.
The first two-thirds of material. the Problem sets were also rather useful in teaching and bridging between concepts.
Shimi is an amazing instructor and is probably the best thing about this course. I can't imagine that it would have been taught better by any other professor.
Great review of chemistry knowledge, very interesting background material on how/why different chemicals affect the environment/us.
The professor. Interesting material, too, but this is probably because he presents it so clearly.
The field trips were the best things about this class because we were able to use the knowledge we had gained in the class.
Clear lectures, teacher cares a lot, good amt of basic background to understand issues with organic pollutants.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Drop the sections on :risk assessment, environmental law and policy, and freeze/thornton. The prof is the best I have ever had for chemistry concepts but by his own admission is not the best at the university to teach these other concepts.As a graduate student, this part of the class seemed to stick out as being very survey/undergrad like, where the prof tries to introduce too many topics without going in sufficient depth in any one area to be very helpful to students preparing research. I think either the previously mentioned sections need to be dropped and more time spent on chemistry concepts or simply don't offer the course at the graduate level.
I felt that too much time was spent on the organic chemistry component of the class and too little time was spent on the different classes of organic pollutants.

The tests were far too broad. We learned A LOT of information in this class and while it is all interesting, I think the professor needs to do a better job of summarizing and emphasizing the MOST important information for memorization. Also the I
Can't think of any.
More about herbicides and pesticides and how they work would be nice.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor and TA were very available and helpful.

Both Shimi and the TAs (Elyssa and Jess) were wonderful! Shimi is a GENIUS! He really understands the material and makes sure to explain it in a way for students to understand. He goes out of his way to help students during his office hours and is always prompt with his email responses. Elyssa and Jess were just as great. They were so helpful during office hours and could make the most complex information understandable. I could tell they both enjoyed the class and it made me like it even more.

The instructor had bountiful help sessions and was willing to just sit by while we did assignments in case we had questions. He very patiently walked me through my more remedial chemistry and math issues and I always left help sessions feeling like I had grasped the material.
Shimi is amazingly available and generous with his time. TAs as well.
Dr. Anisfeld was great at being there for students questions and concerns.
Great from instructor, never had to seek out TAs.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Some of the course material served as a very excellent and needed review for me of basic concepts in organic chemistry; most of it, however, was new material to which I had never been previously exposed. The subjects covered in the last 3/4 of the course are critical to understanding the fate of pollutants in the environment, but for some reason are rarely covered in other courses.

I was hoping that this course would spend more time on endocrine disrupting chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and human waste water treatment. However, the underlying principles that I learned will be helpful in my own learning process.
I'm interested in freshwater ecology, and organic pollutants can be important players in that system.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wished to augment my knowledge of fate and transport of organic pollutants.
Shimon Anisfeld. One of the best professors at FES.
I was hoping that this course would spend more time on endocrine disrupting chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and human waste water treatment.
I need to understand fate and transport of pollution in the environment.
I took this course because of my desire to learn about how pollutants affect the environment.
Love Shimi, love water.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Absolutely, yes.
Yes, absolutely. I just wish it was a longer course...perhaps over two semesters with more in-depth information.
Yes.

This course was a great introduction to organic pollutants and its remediation in the environment. I wish that it didn't give such a general overview of the material, but went more in depth with some of the organic pollutants.
I was hoping that this course would spend more time on endocrine disrupting chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and human waste water treatment.
yes.
Yes it did!
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes.
I was hoping that this course would spend more time on endocrine disrupting chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and human waste water treatment.
yes. though i wish there were a course about metals and non-organic pollutants too. biogeochemistry wasn't quite as useful for this purpose.
I wish I would have taken more time for this class, but yes I did.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start early on the problem sets, and go to all of the field trips.
Put time into the problem sets to ensure you understand the material and start studying early.

Know your chemistry! This is not an easy A course. Be prepared to put in time and effort in order to do well in this course. It's a great class with a great instructor, and the material learned and how it is taught is very much applicable to real life.
Be ready to study A LOT!
don't get behind!
It's a fair amount of work, but worth it.
